content: How can I help you today?

I'm not sure, to be honest. My wife thought it would be good for me to talk, but I just feel stuck and overwhelmed. Things at home and with my family have been really rough lately, and I don’t even know where to start.

It can feel overwhelming when so much feels like it's piling up around you. It took courage to share that, and it's a great first step you're taking by being here. When you say you're feeling stuck and things have been rough, what has been weighing on you the most lately?

I think it’s been dealing with my son’s behavior. He’s been acting out a lot, and my wife and I just can’t seem to figure out how to help him. It’s been really stressful, and it’s honestly wearing down our marriage.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot right now, trying to navigate your son's behavior and the impact it's having on your marriage. That kind of stress can really take a toll. How have you and your wife been managing through all of this so far?

Not very well, to be honest. We try to talk about it, but it usually just turns into frustration with each other. I think we’re both exhausted and don’t even know where to start with my son or with us. It feels like we're stuck in this constant cycle.

It sounds like both of you are feeling exhausted and unsure of how to break out of this pattern, and that's been creating even more tension. That can feel heavy. What do you think might help, even just a little, to bring some relief for you, your wife, or your family in this situation?
I honestly don’t know. Maybe someone who can help us understand what’s going on with my son or even with us. But part of me wonders if it’s even worth trying—it just feels so overwhelming.

It sounds like you’re torn between wanting help and feeling unsure if it will make a difference, especially with how overwhelming everything seems. It’s understandable to feel that way when there’s so much on your shoulders. What keeps you thinking about reaching out for help, even with those doubts?
I guess it’s because deep down I really don’t want to lose my family. I love my wife and kids, and I just want things to feel normal again, but I don’t know where to even start to fix this.

Your love for your family really shines through, even amidst everything you're feeling. Wanting things to feel normal again shows how much you care about them and value those relationships. It’s a lot to take on alone—what might it look like if you had support to help guide you through this?

It might help, I guess. Maybe someone could help me figure out what’s going on with my son and how to handle everything better. But I’m just so used to trying to handle things myself. Opening up like this doesn’t come easy for me.

It’s understandable that opening up might feel uncomfortable, especially if you’re used to handling things on your own. It takes strength to share where you’re at, though, and you’re doing that now, which says a lot about your commitment to your family. What small step do you think might feel manageable for you to take toward getting that kind of support?

Maybe starting with someone who could help us understand my son better would be a step. I feel like if we could figure out what’s going on with him, it could ease some of the stress at home. But I wouldn’t even know who to talk to or where to start looking for that kind of help.

Focusing on understanding your son sounds like a meaningful first step. It’s clear how much you want to support him and your family through this. Finding the right kind of help might feel overwhelming, but there are professionals, like family counselors or child behavioral specialists, who can help guide you. Would it feel helpful to start by exploring resources or asking for recommendations from someone you trust, like your family doctor or a school counselor?
I think I am okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
